title: Peru Two cocaine smuggler admits she ‘sort of’ knew what she was doing
text:
Michaella McCollum said she ‘sort of’ knew what she was doing (Picture: Rex; Getty)

Peru Two mule Michaella McCollum has admitted she ‘sort of’ knew what she was doing when she agreed to smuggle £1.5million worth of cocaine.

The mum-of-two, now 25, was caught with the drugs and arrested at Jorge Chávez International Airport, Lima, in 2013.

She and accomplice Melissa Reid claimed at first they were forced to smuggle the drugs at gunpoint, before pleading guilty in court.

Michaella then spent more than two years locked in a ‘hell-hole’ prison in Peru before she was able to return home.

In an extract from her new book, You’ll Never See Daylight Again, the former waitress admitted partial responsibility for her actions.

She has now written a book about what happened (Picture: Rex Features)

Both women became known as the Peru Two (Picture: Rex Features)

She wrote: ‘Was I guilty? Yes. Did I know what I was doing? Sort of. Was I hung out to dry by a bunch of gangsters and the Peruvian justice system? Absolutely.

Advertisement

‘So why did I do it? Why did I jeopardise everything and bring untold heartache to my adored family for a few easy quid?’

Michaella said she moved to Ibiza aged 19 and quickly became immersed in the island’s party lifestyle, even serving customers drugs with their drinks while working as a waitress.

She then came into contact with a ‘cockney’ drug dealer named Davey, and he offered her the opportunity to ‘run’ drugs in exchange for money.

At first, she refused, but wrote that that the idea must have become ‘lodged’ in her mind, as later, when he approached her again, she said yes.

The drugs were hidden in sachets (Picture: Rex Features)

However, at first she was told she would be picking up the drugs in Barcelona – and when the destination changed to Peru, Michaella claims she didn’t realise she would be leaving Spain.

In her book, which is being serialised in the Mail on Sunday, she said she had ‘no idea’ where Peru was and thought it was ‘another Spanish town’.

It wasn’t until she got chatting to another passenger on her long-haul flight that it dawned on her she was going to South America.

Before the flight, she had been introduced to Melissa, who flew over to Peru the day before her.

Both women then collected the drugs, which were concealed inside 31 sachets of porridge oats and various local soya brands.

Michaella spent two years in a Peruvian prison (Picture: AFP)

Michaella described how they were instructed to visit some of Peru’s most popular attractions and take photos, so that they could cover their tracks if quizzed at the airport.

Advertisement

She was told by Mateo, an associate of Davey, that ‘nothing would happen’ at the airport, as officials had been bribed to ignore anything suspicious.

He also promised her £5,000 in exchange for the safe return of the drugs.

However as soon as they arrived at the airport, Michaella realised the gravity of the situation she had put herself in, with armed guards and sniffer dogs on patrol.

She wrote: ‘Davey’s Colombian friend might have paid a few guards to turn a blind eye, but you’d need to bribe the whole airport to get this amount through.’

They tried at first to claim they had been forced to smuggle the drugs (Picture: AFP)

Her suitcase then passed by the dogs and men armed with machine guns, and when neither moved she thought they had managed to get away with it.

But she then realised Melissa was being ‘led by the arm into a room behind the check-in desk’ with six men holding semi-automatic weapons following her.

Over 11kg of cocaine was found in their suitcases, and both women were jailed for six years in December 2013.

They were released after two years, and Michaella has since gone on to give birth to two twin boys called Rio and Raphael.

Her book will be published on October 31.

description: Peru Two mule Michaella McCollum has admitted she 'sort of' knew what she was doing when she agreed to smuggle £1.5million worth of cocaine.
